question_text: Using the binding energy differences between organic chlorine in PVC (397 kJ/mol) and inorganic chlorine in NaCl (787 kJ/mol), explain how these energy barriers quantitatively determine the temperature-dependent HCl release profiles during MSW incineration. Specifically, analyze how the lower binding energy of PVC enables HCl release at 200-360°C with complete decomposition at ~550°C, while the higher binding energy of inorganic chlorides requires different thermal conditions for transformation.
standard_answer: The binding energy differences between organic and inorganic chlorine sources fundamentally govern their thermal decomposition kinetics and HCl release profiles during MSW incineration. Organic chlorides in PVC have a significantly lower binding energy of 397 kJ/mol compared to inorganic chlorides like NaCl with 787 kJ/mol binding energy. This energy barrier difference directly translates to distinct temperature-dependent release mechanisms. The lower binding energy of PVC enables thermal decomposition through depolymerization mechanisms at relatively low temperatures, where PVC begins releasing HCl between 200°C and 360°C and completely decomposes at approximately 550°C. This occurs because the C-Cl bond energy of 397 kJ/mol can be overcome at these moderate temperatures, allowing for rapid HCl formation during the devolatilization stage. In contrast, the much higher binding energy of inorganic chlorides (787 kJ/mol for NaCl) requires substantially greater thermal energy input to initiate transformation processes. The ionic bonding in inorganic chlorides necessitates higher activation energies for bond breaking and subsequent HCl formation through reactions with other species in the combustion environment. This fundamental difference in bond strengths creates a temporal separation in HCl release profiles, with organic sources dominating early-stage release and inorganic sources contributing through different transformation pathways that require higher thermal energy inputs due to their stronger chemical bonds.
